Posts.EditableText: Hi Alex A new version of Quest is always fun, downloaded 3.5 Pro beta & played with the new bits - so far so good Particularly interested in the ability to open games from a zip - this is cool as it lets us bundle games with images sounds etc, but as far as I can see, still doesn't let us protect the viewing of those which is a pity. Ideally I think we need a zip of resource files that can be password protected - and the password coded into the calling game so that things can only be 'got at' during a game Just a thought. Al
Posts.HTML:
Hi Alex

A new version of Quest is always fun, downloaded 3.5 Pro beta & played with the new bits - so far so good

Particularly interested in the ability to open games from a zip - this is cool as it lets us bundle games with images sounds etc, but as far as I can see, still doesn't let us protect the viewing of those which is a pity.

Ideally I think we need a zip of resource files that can be password protected - and the password coded into the calling game so that things can only be 'got at' during a game

Just a thought.

Al

First bug?

Although it doesn't matter a whole lot to me, I installed the later MS text to speech engine from the Quest website onto my Win98se box. It tests OK and "Microsoft Mary" drones as expected when tested from the control panel.

However $speechenabled$ returns 0 in Quest 3.5 beta and (unsurprisingly) speech output using "speak" does not work.

Just thought you ought to know - Oh and I realised the ASL version ought to be 350 as that is what QDK outputs.

Al
